data.text: 1.1.1 The emergence of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-

2) was declared a global public health emergency by the WHO on 30th January  2020. The failure to control the virus early in the outbreak prompted the WHO to  upgrade their characterisation to that of global pandemic.

1.1.2 SARS-CoV-2 can cause lower respiratory tract infections, referred to as COVID-19.  Typically, symptoms include a persistent cough, fever, shortness of breath and the  loss of smell and/or taste. In those without co-morbidities, the infection is often  asymptomatic or may present as a mild flu-like infection that is self-limiting. In those  with co-morbidities, this disease will often progress to viral pneumonia that may  require hospitalisation.

1.1.3 The  SARS-Cov-2  antigen  rapid  test  is  a  colloidal  gold  immunochromatography  method intended for the qualitative detection of nucleocapsid antigens from SARS- CoV-2 in human nasal swabs or throat swabs from individuals who are suspected of  COVID-19 by their healthcare provider within the first five days of the onset of  symptoms. This test is to aid the early diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 infection in patient  with  clinical  symptoms  with  SARS-CoV-2  infection.  It  provides  only  an  initial  screening test result. The result of this test should not be the sole basis for the  diagnosis; confirmatory testing is required.
1.2.1 This reagent is based on colloidal gold immunochromatography assay.

1.2.2 During the test, specimen extracts are applied to the test cartridges. If there were  SARSCoV-2  antigen  in  the  extract,  the  antigen  will  bind  to  the  SARS-CoV-2  monoclonal  antibody.  During  lateral  flow,  the  complex  will  move  along  the  nitrocellulose membrane toward the end of the absorbent paper. When passing the  test  line  (line  T,  coated  with  another  SARS-CoV-2  monoclonal  antibody)  the  complex is captured by SARS-CoV-2 antibody on test line resulting in colouring on  line  T;  when  passing  the  line  C,  colloidal  gold-labelled  goat  anti-rabbit  IgG  is  captured by control line (line C, coated with rabbit IgG) resulting in colouring on line

Point of Care Testing (POCT) is an established part of clinical practice, offering in  many instances, rapid and convenient provision of test results that can be of benefit  to the patient. It is however, a significant risk management issue for the Trust.  Results obtained by non-specialist staff carry as much weight in patient  management as results from sophisticated equipment in the care of professional  laboratory staff. Incorrect results have the same health and legal implications,  whatever their origin.

The purpose of this document is to ensure reliable performance and management of the risks associated with testing outside the main laboratory. This procedure describes correct use of POCT equipment in order to minimise risk to both patient and user, and ensure consistent procedures are in place throughout the Trust.

Individuals who have not been trained and competency assessed in the use of the Innova SARS-CoV-2 antigen lateral flow test are not authorised to use these devices. This document has not been written as a substitute for practical training and competency assessment.

table_items.text: e The performance of analytical tests on patient specimens outside th laboratory by non-laboratory staff
Any individual using a POCT device

T d Internal quality control (QC) is a means of determining that the POC equipment is technically performing correctly at that specific time an that the patient result is reliable before it is released and acted on.
Simple to use diagnostic device used to confirm the presence or absence of a target analyte (e.g. SARS-Cov-2 antigen)

data.text: The POCT committee is responsible for overseeing and co-ordinating all aspects of the POCT service within their Trust. Clinical Governance for POCT services is provided through the POCT policy. This policy is reviewed and updated every 2 years.

Teams should be adequately resourced to enable them to implement and monitor compliance with the POCT policy and procedure. They are responsible for ensuring any recommendations imposed on the service by the committee are carried out.

As the accountable officer, has overall responsibility for ensuring the Trust has robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal, and national requirements are met.
Responsible for the implementation of this policy.

data.url: MSEGL-21006 Innova sars-cov-2 antigen lateral flow test 1.0.003.png

data.text: Holds the ultimate responsibility for Point of Care Testing as guardian of Clinical  Governance.
Advises and arbitrates if necessary if agreement about the introduction of a  POCT service cannot be reached.
Ensures guidelines are in place for interpretation of results and further patient  management.
Has clinical oversight for Point of Care Testing, liaising on matters including  current testing protocols and implementation of new equipment/ tests.
Reviews POCT EQA and reports upon it.
Heads of Nursing and Midwifery and Matrons
Heads of Nursing and Midwifery and Matrons have a responsibility to ensure correct  procedures are followed.
To take on managerial ownership of any POCT equipment within their area and to  ensure that it is maintained and used correctly.
They will ensure the competency of all users of POCT in their area. They will  keep records of initial training, competency statements and update training.

If appropriate they will appoint a link person to oversee the day-to-day operation  of POCT equipment within their area. The use of a Link Person does not absolve  the ward/department manager of full responsibility for POCT

Where there has been an incident involving POCT devices, including inadequate  performance or documentation of patient or Quality Assurance results, Ward or  Departmental managers will investigate the incident and be responsible for  reporting this to POCT. All such incidents should be brought to the attention of  the POCT manager and the POCT committee.
Any request for new, upgraded or replacement POCT processes must be  submitted to the POCT committee for approval. This includes free, trial and loan  devices.
Point of Care Testing Link Person

A Link Person may be designated within a ward/department for the purpose of  ensuring the day to day operation of POCT systems, ensuring equipment is  functioning and necessary consumables are available. They may provide cascade  training, having been trained to a high level of competence, ensuring staff  undertaking POCT are suitable to do so.
Pharmacy is responsible for standardising, ordering and supplying the majority of  POCT consumables as directed by the POCT committee.

data.url: MSEGL-21006 Innova sars-cov-2 antigen lateral flow test 1.0.003.png

data.text: The POCT service managers monitor the POCT service within each Trust. They  ensure that POCT policies and procedures are adhered to and that adequate  resources and support are available to facilitate a safe and reliable service.
To identify areas of clinical need where the introduction of POCT could be  appropriate and provide the information necessary for the cost-benefit analysis.
To approach POCT in the spirit of the policy and not to attempt to introduce new  testing without referring to the POCT policy.
To undertake POCT themselves only after adequate training and certification.
To be familiar with the information provided by and shortcomings of the POCT  results that they use for their patient management.
To ensure that results of POCT are recorded accurately, unequivocally and  safely and that information about tests upon which they base patient  management decisions can be retrieved in retrospect.
The responsibility for patient results obtained using POCT and therapeutic decisions  based on those results lies with the requesting clinician for the ward/department.

The individual conducting the analysis is accountable for the results they generate  using POCT devices. They must ensure their POCT training is up to date and that  their competence is maintained. It is the responsibility of the user:

To follow procedures as set out in the documented Standard Operating  Procedure, including sample taking and handling, instrument checks and/or  Quality Control, recording of results and disposal of consumables.
To undertake and record External Quality Control analysis as required.

To report suspect Quality Control results or possible instrument malfunction  immediately to the Link person or person in charge at the time and to stop  using the equipment until the matter has been resolved.
To report abnormal or suspect patient results to the responsible person  immediately
To report adverse incidents related to POCT devices to the Link nurse where  used and to the POCT team.
Treat all patients' samples as highly infectious. Use proper care and techniques to  not contaminate yourself. Wear clean and appropriate PPE (i.e. gloves, apron,  FRMS, eye protection).

data.url: MSEGL-21006 Innova sars-cov-2 antigen lateral flow test 1.0.003.png

data.text: 5.1.2.1  Follow local procedures and guidelines for disposal of clinical waste. Used/expired  test kits should be disposed of into clinical waste bags immediately. All swabs  should be disposed into sharps bins.
Use appropriate disinfectant for any biological fluid spillages immediately. Chemical  spillages should not apply.
Wash  hands  thoroughly  after  each  test.  Do  not  smoke,  eat  or  drink  whilst  performing any part of this test

data.url: MSEGL-21006 Innova sars-cov-2 antigen lateral flow test 1.0.004.png

data.text: Store the testing kit material at 2-30°C, in dry condition and out of direct sunlight.  Shelf life is tentatively 24 months.
Reagents and devices  must be at room temperature (15-30°C)  when used for  testing.
Do not use expired test kits.

Results are manually read by eye, so a good light source is required and a stop  watch/timer to time analysis. Read the test result between 20-30 minutes. Results  are invalid if read after 30 minutes.
Supplies of testing kits will be available from your local site pathology department.

data.text: The test kits have an inbuilt control which will confirm if the right amount of sample  has been added and that the device has worked correctly.

data.text: IQC will be run by the POC/Pathology department as appropriate :
To investigate suspected false positive/false negative results
To investigate the cause of repeated invalid results

data.text: All test results must be recorded on the results form (see appendix 1), along with lot  number and operator identification. This is in addition to recording the result in the  clinical area's usual documentation e.g. case notes, A&E card etc…
Do not discard the results recording form. These will be required to report results  back to Public Health England (PHE) via their POC results portal.
These results sheets will be periodically collected by the POC testing team for safe  storage.
It is a legal requirement for all LFD results to be reported directly to PHE via the  POC reporting portal at least weekly.

data.url: MSEGL-21006 Innova sars-cov-2 antigen lateral flow test 1.0.003.png

data.text: Line C must be coloured to have a valid test result.
Negative: There is colouration on the C line only
Positive: There is colouration on both the C and T lines
Note: the presence of any line in the T window, no matter how faint is considered  positive. Positive results should be considered in conjunction with the clinical history  and other data available.
Invalid results: There is no colouration on the C line. The test is invalid or an error  in operation occurred. Repeat the test with a new cartridge.

data.url: MSEGL-21006 Innova sars-cov-2 antigen lateral flow test 1.0.012.png

data.text: 6.3.1  The performance of the Biotime SARS-CoV-2 Antigen Rapid Qualitative Test for  rapid detection of SARS-CoV-2 was established with  direct nasal swab or  throat  swab  prospectively  collected  and  enrolled  from  individual  symptomatic  patients (within 5 days of onset) who were spected of COVID-19. As with all antigen  tests, performance may decrease as days since symptom onset increases. For  each type, four kinds of samples from the same person were tested by Company's  Kit. We selected 25 positive and 25 negative sample. P1-P25 of samples are from  infected  people,  and  NI-N25  are  from  uninfected  people.  P21-P25  are  weekly  positive.
95% Confidence Interval  Relative Sensitivity  72/75  96% (88.75 – 99.17)  Relative Specificity  220/220  100% (98.34 – 100)  Accuracy  292/295  98.98% (97.06 – 99.79)

6.4.1  There are several factors that may lead to uncertainty of results. Incorrect sample handling,  storage  conditions, delays  in  processing  the  samples  and  insufficient mixing prior to mixing may lead to ‘false' results. It is therefore important to follow the instructions detailed in this SOP.
Do not reuse the test kit
Do not use the test kit if the pouch is damaged or the seal is broken
Positive test results do not rule out co-infections with other pathogens

A false negative test result may occur if the level of viral antigen in a sample is below the detection limit of the test or if the sample was collected or transported improperly. Therefore a negative test result does not eliminate the possibility of SARS-Cov-2 infection
The amount of antigen in a sample may decrease as the duration of illness increases. Specimens collected after day 5 of illness are more likely to be negative compared to a RT-PCR assay.
Individuals carrying out Innova SARS-Cov-2 antigen test should have received adequate training and be confirmed as competent via competency assessment (see appendix 2).

data.text: All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Pathology  Governance Committee, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve  local local policies and procdures. These will then be forwarded to the Document  control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management  Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the users of the approved policy documents  when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and  meets the needs of all individuals.
Lateral flow device testing for emergency department patient pathways. NHSE 24  December 2020. Version 1.
INNOVA SARS-COV-2 information for user guide
NB: Only staff trained and competency assessed to perform this test should carry out POCT COVID-19 Ag testing.
Results to be uploaded to PHE portal, then return form to POCT Team, Pathology

Appendix 2: Competency Assessment for the INNOVA SARS–CoV-2 Rapid Test

table_items.text: Is aware of the Trust SOP for the INNOVA SARS–CoV-2 Rapid Test
Observe universal precautions (e.g. wears gloves etc.)
Knows the correct storage conditions and shelf life of the kit
Understands what the control line (QC) is for and that the test is invalid if the control line is not present
Competent in nasopharangeal swab sample collection (including ensuring patient blows nose prior to test)
Aware of the requirement for patient ID on the cassette (sticker or handwritten hospital number)
Can demonstrate correct use of the kit as per the SOP
Demonstrates correct use of the extraction solution
Demonstrates correct technique with the specimen extraction
Demonstrates correct technique with specimen application to the cassette
Is aware of the importance of setting a timer and reading the results no later than 30 minutes after application of the specimen
Can accurately interpret and record results
Knows where to store the INNOVA SARS–CoV-2 Rapid Test result work list for the POCT team
Understands correct disposal of clinical waste
Understands in which clinical situations the test is most useful and
Knows who to contact in case of issues with the kit/test
